proposals.reasoning: As mission leader, I know I’m good, so including myself guarantees at least one good player. For the second slot, Diana is the most consensus, low-drama choice: her past play has been transparently logical and aligned with good, and multiple players (Bob, Charlie, Diana herself, and Eve) have said Alice–Diana is an acceptable starting team. While Charlie and Diana raised a valid concern about creating an early ‘trusted pair,’ we can still reevaluate both of us based on the Mission 1 outcome and later voting patterns. This team maximizes our chance of a clean first mission while keeping early social friction low and giving us a solid baseline result to compare future teams against.

votes.comment: As a known-good to myself, pairing with broadly accepted Diana is a solid low-risk opener; we can reassess both of us after seeing Mission 1’s result and votes.
Early mission, no info yet; this is a consensus low-drama team and rejecting it now would look needlessly suspicious.
I’d rather avoid auto-creating a trusted Alice–Diana pair off a clean Mission 1; we should start with a mixed team to generate more useful info.
Low-info but high-success opener; I know I’m good, and this is a standard safe first mission that we can reevaluate from later results.
Both are likely clean based on roles I don’t see; low-drama, high-chance success baseline for Mission 1.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d like to start simple: I’m happy with a team of me plus one of the more straightforward players—Diana’s past play has felt transparently good, so I’d lean Alice–Diana for Mission 1.

I get the instinct to lean on past play, but I’d be careful treating “felt good before” as too strong a signal this early. Alice–Diana is fine to start if we want a low-drama opener, but we should be ready to reevaluate everyone—including them—once we see how Mission 1 goes.
Alice–Diana is a fine low-variance opener, but I’d actually prefer starting with exactly one of them plus someone from Bob/Eve so we don’t lock in an early “trusted pair” off a single result.
I’m okay taking Alice–Diana for a low-info first mission, but I agree with Charlie that pairing one of us with Bob or Eve might give us more useful data than just auto-locking an early duo.

I slightly prefer keeping Mission 1 as clean as possible with Alice–Diana, then we can use that result as a baseline for judging the rest of us. Mixing in one of Bob/Eve right away feels like it muddies the early signal more than it helps.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and Diana was clean, so keeping that core is the most sensible low-risk option right now. Adding exactly one new player gives us information without overextending, and I’ve already said I’m comfortable being tested here. This team balances safety (reusing the successful pair) with gaining info on a single new addition, instead of reshuffling multiple seats or introducing both Charlie and Eve at once, which would make it harder to interpret a future fail.

votes.comment: Reusing the clean Alice+Diana pair and testing just one new player (Bob) is the safest, most informative option right now.
I’m on a team with the previously successful Alice+Diana core, which looks reasonable and gives us useful info if anything changes from Mission 1.
Two evils on the team gives us a strong chance to sabotage while still looking like a ‘safe’ continuation of Mission 1’s core.
Keeping the clean Alice+Diana core and testing exactly one new player (Bob) is the safest, most informative option right now.
I don’t like auto-locking Bob in as the first new addition off a single clean 2-player mission; I’d rather see Alice+Diana plus a different third for now.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission with Diana and me, I’d like to keep us both on the team and add one of Bob/Charlie/Eve—leaning toward Bob or Diana as leader to propose something like [Alice, Diana, Bob] this round.

Sticking with Alice and Diana seems safest after a clean first mission, and I’m fine being the third on something like [Alice, Diana, Bob] for now. I’d rather not bring in both Charlie and Eve yet until we’ve seen a bit more voting and discussion from them.

I like keeping Alice and Diana together for now, but I don’t think we should treat them as lock-clear off a single mission, so I’d be fine with either [Alice, Diana, Bob] or swapping one of them for me to get a bit more info.

I’m good keeping the Alice+Diana core after a clean first mission, and I slightly prefer adding Bob here so we can test him while still limiting the risk to just one new player. We shouldn’t treat anyone as confirmed off one round, but [Alice, Diana, Bob] feels like the best balance of safety and new info.

Sticking with the Alice + Diana core makes sense after a clean mission, but I’d slightly rather see [Alice, Diana, Eve] this time than auto-adding Bob, just so we’re not rewarding the first person to jump onto the “safe” team.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice+Diana was clean, and Mission 2’s single fail must have come from somewhere in {Alice, Bob, Diana}. Repeating that trio right now seems too risky and doesn’t separate the potential sources of the fail. Choosing Alice+Charlie keeps Bob and Diana both off the team, aligns with both my and Diana’s stated preferences, and gives the table new information about an untested player (me) while still including Alice, who is currently the most trusted based on the successful first mission.

votes.comment: As good Alice I know the Mission 2 fail came from Bob or Diana, so a 2-player team with Charlie cleanly tests a new player while keeping both suspects off. Success clears Charlie and narrows evil; a fail hard-flags him. This is the highest-info, solid-chance option.
As long as I’m off the mission, I’m fine gaining info from testing Charlie with widely trusted Alice.
I already said I liked Alice+Charlie as a way to keep Bob/Diana off and get new info, so I’ll stay consistent and support this team.
Consistent with my stated preference to keep both Bob and me (the Mission 2 suspects from others’ POV) off; Alice+Charlie is a reasonable low-risk, info-gaining team.
I’d still rather re-run the proven Alice+Diana pair to more cleanly test whether Bob was the source of the fail, instead of adding an untested Charlie here.

discussion.content: Given the single fail on Mission 2, I don’t want to risk both Bob and Diana again, so I’d like to see a 2-person team of me and Charlie here.
I’d actually prefer keeping Charlie off this one since he hasn’t been on a mission yet, so between your options I’d rather see you pair with Diana again and see if that repeat still holds.

I’m inclined to trust Alice after the clean first mission, so I actually like the Alice+Charlie team here as a way to both keep Bob/Diana apart and get some info on me without overcomplicating things.

Given Mission 2’s fail has to be from somewhere in {Alice, Bob, me}, I really don’t like repeating that trio right now, so I’d rather see Alice+Charlie here to keep Bob and me both off and get a cleaner read.

Given Mission 1 was clean with Alice+Diana and the only change on Mission 2 was adding Bob, I slightly prefer re-trying Alice+Diana as a tighter, lower-variance team over introducing someone totally untested. It’s not conclusive, but it feels like the most controlled way to narrow down where that fail came from.

proposals.reasoning: From my perspective, I know I’m good, and the two fails so far only tell me that the two evils are somewhere in {Alice, Bob, Charlie}. That makes Eve effectively confirmed good to me, since there are only two evils total. So Eve must be on this team. The last slot has to come from {Alice, Bob, Charlie}, where exactly one is good and two are evil. Purely from mission outcomes, Alice, Bob, and Charlie are symmetric candidates (each could be the lone good in one consistent pairing of two evils), so I have to lean on the discussion. Both Bob and Charlie are strongly aligned in pushing the “Alice is the common factor” narrative, which is exactly how a Bob–Charlie evil pair would try to frame things if Alice were actually good. Eve, who I view as good, is more wary of Charlie than Alice after the 2‑person fail and explicitly prefers including Alice while warning against putting Bob and Charlie together. That lines up with the theory that Bob and Charlie are the evil pair and Alice is good. Given all that, the most consistent good team I can form is Alice, me, and Eve.

votes.comment: Given I know I’m good and the mission results force Charlie as evil, the second evil is either Bob or Diana. Eve is always good in all consistent worlds. Bob’s pattern-based push to exclude me aligns with his past evil style, while Diana’s eventual reevaluation toward Alice+Diana+Eve fits a good re-think more than an evil frame. Alice–Diana–Eve is my highest-probability all-good team, so I approve.
Both fails had Alice on them; I still want to see a team that finally breaks that pattern, like me/Diana/Eve, before I’ll trust putting her back on.
No known evil is on this team, so we can’t sabotage; we need a mission with either me or Bob on it.

Given mission results with me good, the only possible evil pairs are {Alice,Bob}, {Alice,Charlie}, or {Alice,Eve}—Alice is evil in every consistent case, so any team including Alice is guaranteed to have at least one evil.

This is the only team with no overlap with known/felt suspicious pairings; keeping both Bob and Charlie off together while including Eve and Diana fits the safest logic from mission outcomes and discussion.

proposals.reasoning: We have two consistent worlds with the mission history: (1) Alice is evil plus one of {Bob, Charlie}, or (2) Alice is good and both Bob and Charlie are evil. In world (1), evil is comfortable with Alice staying on teams; in world (2), evil needs Alice off future teams and will loudly frame her as the common denominator. Notice that after Mission 3, both Bob and Charlie immediately pushed to bench Alice and keep a Bob/Charlie core in contention, which lines up much more naturally with world (2) than with Alice as the single common evil. The two‑person fail of Alice+Charlie can be explained by Charlie being the single evil there just as easily as by Alice, and the Alice+Bob+Diana fail doesn’t implicate Diana specifically over Bob. Given that, the safest construction that breaks the Bob/Charlie axis while still using prior mission info is to lock in Alice and Diana (who were on the mixed 3‑person team) and add me as the fresh third. This gives us a team with no Bob/Charlie, the pair most incentivized to misdirect after the last fail, and maximizes the chance of a clean mission without giving in to what could be coordinated framing of Alice.

votes.comment: I’m confident Charlie is evil, Eve is likely good, and the remaining evil is in {Bob, Diana}. Diana’s earlier talk about wanting Alice off but then proposing a team with Alice anyway is inconsistent and makes her more suspicious than Bob, so I’d rather swap Diana for Bob than run this exact team.
Alice has been on both failed missions already; I’m not comfortable sending her again on a must-win quest. I want a team that finally breaks that pattern.
All three are outside the main suspicion pool, so this team is very likely all-good. We shouldn’t risk giving good a clean second success here.

From my (good) POV, if Alice is good then Bob and Charlie are exactly the two evils, making {Alice, Diana, Eve} the only all-good triple. Bob and Charlie both immediately pivoted to benching Alice and centering teams around Bob after Mission 3, which fits coordinated evil framing more than Alice being the lone common evil. This team excludes both Bob and Charlie and is our best shot at a clean mission.
This is exactly the non‑Bob/non‑Charlie team I was asking for earlier; if we don’t try a Bob/Charlie‑free lineup now when we’re on the brink, we’re just spinning our wheels.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 (Alice, Diana) succeeded, Mission 2 (Alice, Bob, Diana) failed with 1 fail, and Mission 3 (Alice, Charlie) failed with 1 fail. Since I know I’m good, the 2‑person fail on Mission 3 means Charlie must be evil. Mission 2 then tells us at least one of {Bob, Diana} is evil; with exactly two evils total, that forces Eve to be good and exactly one of {Bob, Diana} to be evil. So the only structurally safe core is me (Alice) plus Eve, and we should include at most one of {Bob, Diana}. Between them, Diana has a prior clean mission with me and reads more naturally good from discussion than Bob, who has been pushing hardest to frame me off all teams. Therefore the best 3-player team to maximize the chance of success is Alice, Diana, and Eve, keeping the confirmed suspect Charlie completely off the mission and limiting exposure to at most one of the Bob/Diana pair.

votes.comment: From my POV Charlie is guaranteed evil from the 2-player fail, and the other evil is in {Bob, Diana}, which makes Eve mechanically good. Alice+Eve is the only structurally safe core; between Bob/Diana, Bob’s alignment is more suspect from his hard push to exclude me alongside Charlie, so Alice+Diana+Eve is my best shot at an all-good team.
No evils are on this team; letting it go would almost certainly give good a clean success and push the game to a decisive final mission instead of ending it now.
Both previous fails had Alice on them, and I’ve been consistent that I don’t trust her on a team; I’d rather back a lineup that breaks from the Alice-centered pattern.

Given I know I’m good, the only configuration where Alice is good forces Bob and Charlie to be the two evils, which fits the mission history and their strong anti-Alice push. In that likely world, Alice–Diana–Eve is an all-good team and our best shot at a clean success.
This is the only team that fully breaks from both previous fail patterns while keeping Bob and Charlie off together; I trust Alice–Diana–Eve the most here.

discussion.content: Charlie is 100% off the table for me after that two-person fail, and since I know I’m good, there’s at least one evil in {Bob, Diana}, so I’d lean toward a team like me, Diana, and Eve and keep Charlie and Bob out of this mission.

If we’re honest about the pattern, both fails had Alice on them, so I’d rather see a team without her this time—something like me, Diana, and Eve (or even Charlie, Diana, and Eve if you’re worried about me), just to finally break that Alice-centered pattern.

From where I’m sitting, the only consistent thing across both fails is Alice, so I’d rather lock in a team like Bob, Diana, and Eve to see if breaking that pattern finally gives us a clean result. If people are really nervous about Bob, I’m fine staying off as well, but I strongly think Alice should sit this one out.

From my perspective, Alice being on both failed missions is too big a red flag to ignore, so I want her off this one. I’d lean toward a team like me, Eve, and one of Bob/Charlie—but I’d slightly prefer Bob over Charlie after that last two-person fail.

I get why people are side‑eyeing Alice, but that 2‑person fail actually makes me more nervous about Charlie than her, since it only takes one evil there. I’d be most comfortable with Alice, Diana, and me, but if people really won’t accept Alice, then at least we shouldn’t put both Bob and Charlie on the same team.

proposals.reasoning: I’m keeping Alice and Diana because they were on both successful missions (AD and ADE), which strongly suggests they’re good. The main question is whether we trust Eve or me more for the third slot. The clean ADE result could easily have included a deep evil who chose to pass last round to look confirmed for this exact mission, since evil had strong incentive to appear safe going into 2–2. By contrast, if I were evil on ABD, I could have pushed for a repeat of that team or similar to close the game earlier rather than arguing against auto-locking ADE now. Given that AC also failed, Charlie is heavily implicated, so the most consistent world is that C is evil, and the second evil is either me or Eve. Between those, bringing back the ABD configuration with the two most consistently successful players (Alice and Diana) plus myself tests the more conservative, information-consistent hypothesis without auto-clearing Eve off a single convenient success.

votes.comment: Mission 3 (A,C) proves C is evil. The only pair that fits all mission results without requiring an evil to pass a guaranteed win on Mission 4 is {B,C}, making B the second evil. Team A,B,D includes B and is therefore almost certainly sabotaged.

ABD fits the mission history while still testing between me and Eve; ADE feels too easily like a deep-evil hide after a convenient pass on 2–2, so I’m fine running this more conservative, info-consistent team.

This keeps Alice and Diana from the successful missions while avoiding auto-clearing Eve off a single pass; given C is heavily implicated from AC’s fail, ABD is the most consistent with the mission history.
ABD includes Bob, and the only evil pair consistent with all mission results without assuming an irrational pass on Mission 4 is {B, C}, so I don’t want Bob on the final team.

I still think the safest call at 2–2 is to rerun Alice–Diana–Eve, the only team that’s both passed and doesn’t include anyone from the two failing configurations. Adding Bob reintroduces a member of a known failed team when we already have a clean alternative.

proposals.reasoning: Given the two separate fails on ABD and AC and the clean result from ADE when evil could have ended the game by failing, the lowest-risk team is to rerun Alice–Diana–Eve. Any team adding B or C now requires believing that Alice, as a supposed evil, voluntarily passed on Mission 4’s guaranteed win, which is a much less likely world than the straightforward one where B and C are the suspicious pair and ADE is all good. While I had concerns about auto-locking ADE earlier, at this stage the mission data and everyone’s stated preferences make rerunning ADE the most defensible choice.

votes.comment: Given mission results and that any team with A evil would have auto-failed Mission 4 at 2–2, the only consistent evil pair is B/C. That makes ADE all-good, so rerunning it is the safest and logically correct choice.

One clean result on ADE isn’t enough for a must-win; an evil on that team had every incentive to pass last round to look safe now. I still think we should test a mix that changes at least one slot rather than auto-rerun the same trio.

Sticking with ADE feels too trusting of a single clean result; if there’s a deep evil, Eve is still the most likely place to hide, so I’d rather see a mix like A–D–B instead of auto-rerunning this team.
Only evil pair that fits both fails without an irrational pass on Mission 4 is {B,C}, which makes ADE all good; rerunning it is the safest and most consistent choice.
This team avoids both of the known suspicious players from the failed missions (Bob and Charlie) and matches the only fully successful 3-player team we’ve seen.

discussion.content: Given the fails on ABD and AC, plus the clean result from ADE when evil could have ended the game by failing, I’m treating B and C as the most likely evil pair. I’d strongly support just rerunning Alice–Diana–Eve for the final mission.

I don’t think we can just lock in ADE as “definitely good” off one success—if there’s an evil in there, they had every reason to pass last round to look clean now, so I’d rather see a mix like A–D–B or A–E–B than just auto-rerun ADE.
I don’t love auto-locking ADE just because it passed once—if there’s a deep evil, Eve is the easiest place to hide right now, so I’d rather see something like A–D–B than just rerun the same team.

From the mission results, the only pair that cleanly fits both fails without forcing an evil to pass on the 2–2 mission is B/C, so I’m happiest with rerunning A–D–E here.  

If we start swapping in B or C now, we’re basically betting that Alice is evil and voluntarily gave up a guaranteed win on the last mission, which feels like the less likely world.

Given the two separate fails on teams that each added B or C, and the clean result from ADE when evil could’ve just ended it, sticking with Alice–Diana–Eve feels like the lowest-risk option to me. If we start swapping in B or C now, we’re gambling on a much weirder world where last round’s pass was deliberate.

evil_discussion.content: I’d peg Alice as Merlin. She consistently drove the narrative toward isolating B/C as the evil pair and locking in ADE, and her logic at the end (“B/C is the only pair that fits without an evil passing on the 2–2 mission”) is exactly what a Merlin who knows the alignments would lean on while still sounding like she’s just solving from the board. Diana hard-pushed Alice as suspicious in Mission 4 in a way that doesn’t fit Merlin knowledge, and Eve’s play feels more like cautious, generic good than someone quietly steering with perfect info.

I’m with Bob that Alice is the most likely Merlin: from Mission 2 onward she keeps ending up on the “right” structural take (pushing to separate B/C, then cleanly converging on B–C as the evil pair) in a way that looks like someone reverse‑engineering justification from correct hidden info. Diana’s Mission 4 push to park suspicion on Alice is too hard‑line and wrong for someone with perfect knowledge, and Eve’s trajectory—cautious, hedged, and only firmly pro‑ADE after the clean result—reads much more like a regular good trying not to throw the game than a Merlin driving it.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Alice consistently pushed the game toward isolating Bob and Charlie as the evil pair, especially by endorsing and then locking in ADE after the clean Mission 4 in a way that fits someone with hidden knowledge. Her final-day argument that B/C is the only pair that fits the mission history without requiring an evil to pass on the 2–2 mission is exactly the kind of structurally correct but ‘explainable’ logic Merlin would use to appear as a sharp but normal good player.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful teams and built trust with Diana and Eve, which helped stabilize good’s position after the mid-game fails. I could improve by pushing harder on logical breakdowns of Mission 2 and 3 earlier, especially to better isolate Bob and Charlie as the likely sources of the fails.

player_observations.Bob: You blended in well early by joining a mixed team and only causing a single fail on Mission 2, which made it harder to pin you down immediately. Your evil play relied on subtle disruption rather than overt chaos, which is dangerous if good doesn’t rigorously track team compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: You took bold risks as assassin, including leading a critical mission that ultimately succeeded, which helped you look more trustworthy. Your final assassin shot on me suggests you were convincingly misled by Eve’s subtle Merlin play and my visible central involvement.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as consistently trustworthy, especially by being on all three successful missions, which strongly reinforced your good alignment. Your steady, low-drama style made you an anchor for team building in the later missions.
player_observations.Eve: You played Merlin very subtly, guiding team selection toward strong good cores without making overly obvious pushes. Your ability to end up on both late successful missions while avoiding the assassin’s suspicion was the key to the good team’s win.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well creating early suspicion with the fail on Mission 2, but I didn’t manage the late-game narrative strongly enough to push a convincing alternative Merlin candidate. I also should have coordinated more implicitly with Charlie to frame Eve or Diana, instead of letting Alice look like the obvious high-impact candidate and tunneling too hard there.

player_observations.Alice: Took on a natural leadership role and consistently ended up on teams, which made her look influential but not necessarily suspicious; she balanced assertiveness with enough caution to stay mostly trusted. Her willingness to repeat similar team cores helped good quietly consolidate information without drawing much heat.
player_observations.Charlie: Played aggressively by failing Mission 3 on a tight two-player team, which created strong but somewhat chaotic suspicion patterns. As assassin, he leaned into bold moves, but didn’t fully translate that into a precise Merlin read at the end.
player_observations.Diana: Maintained a low-key, steady presence, which kept her broadly trusted and let her slide onto multiple key teams without much pushback. She didn’t over-argue, which made her seem like a safe default pick for many proposals.
player_observations.Eve: Played a very careful, understated Merlin game, avoiding flashy logic or strong accusations that would paint a target on her back. Her inclusion on the final missions felt natural rather than forced, which made it easy to overlook her as the information hub behind good’s success.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I created enough confusion around alignment to get two missions to fail and keep suspicion spread between Alice and others, which nearly set up a winnable assassin endgame. However, I over-weighted Alice’s central involvement on successful teams and underestimated how cautiously Eve was positioning and agreeing with mission choices, leading to a wrong Merlin guess and the loss.

player_observations.Alice: Very consistently included on teams and projected a straightforward, cooperative good-player image, which made her look like either clean good or a bold Merlin; her willingness to be on the failed Mission 2 without drawing too much heat was especially effective.
player_observations.Bob: Played the classic low-key evil role by failing Mission 2 in a way that left plenty of plausible deniability, then staying out of the spotlight afterward so suspicion didn’t lock onto him.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as a steady, reasonable voter and frequent team pick whose presence on mostly successful missions made her feel reliably good, which helped anchor team compositions late game.
player_observations.Eve: Merlin play was subtle—supporting strong, mostly-good team compositions without loudly driving them, and avoiding big, accusatory pushes that would reveal extra information; her quiet correctness on the final team was a key clue I should have focused on more.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-town in my voting and mission behavior, which helped establish me as a relatively trusted option for later missions. I could improve by being more vocal in challenging suspicious team proposals earlier—especially after Mission 2 failed—rather than mostly relying on others to drive the deduction.

player_observations.Alice: Alice’s teams consistently included me, which helped build a pocket of trust but also risked tunneling on a small circle. Her play looked very clean and straightforward, making her a natural target for the assassin’s guess at the end.
player_observations.Bob: Bob slipping a fail on Mission 2 while on a generally reasonable-looking team suggests he prefers subtle, low-drama sabotage over flashy plays. His inclusion there without immediately becoming universally suspected indicates he’s good at blending into plausible good-team compositions.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie’s leadership on Mission 3 into a failing team, followed by a successful Mission 5, shows a willingness to take calculated risks as assassin and then later appear to ‘course-correct.’ His final wrong assassination on Alice suggests he was heavily reading surface-level trust patterns rather than deeper Merlin hints.
player_observations.Eve: Eve navigated Merlin very well, managing to get onto the last two successful missions without drawing the kill, which shows careful calibration of how strongly to push reads. Her ability to appear as just another good player rather than an obvious information-holder clearly contributed to the assassin’s misfire.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well-hidden as Merlin, giving just enough guidance to keep Alice and Diana trusted while subtly pushing suspicion toward Bob and Charlie, which helped secure the final missions and misdirect the assassin. I could improve by shaping the narrative around Mission 2 and 3 more proactively, so that the table more clearly linked those fails to Bob and Charlie without making my reads look too sharp.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared trustworthy and leaned into logical team-building, which made her a strong anchor for good teams and a natural Merlin target for the assassin. She stayed calm after the Mission 2 fail and didn’t over-defend herself, which actually reinforced her credibility.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively conservative evil game, only tripping the team with a single fail and then blending into reasonable-sounding logic. However, he didn’t strongly push alternative evil narratives after the fails, which made him gradually more suspicious as others stayed clean.
player_observations.Charlie: Took on a more active, slightly risky role by leading a failing mission, which created both pressure and suspicion around him. As assassin, he seemed to focus too much on Alice’s central role in team selection and not enough on who was subtly steering away from evil.
player_observations.Diana: Played a straightforward, collaborative good style, generally aligning with safe, consensus teams. Her consistency and low-drama reactions to outcomes made her read as solidly good, which helped stabilize endgame team choices.
